description: Westside in Salisbury features modest homes from the 1930s-40s, some backing onto Johnson Pond. It’s near downtown and Lake Street Park. Charles H. Chipman Elementary School is highly rated.

name: O'Donnell Heights
description: O'Donnell Heights in Baltimore blends older row homes and newer townhouses. The Shops at Canton Crossing has national retailers, and Cimaglia Park features basketball courts. Locals can get downtown on the CityLink Navy bus line.

name: Park Circle
description: Park Circle, less than 4 miles from downtown, offers historic row houses and Pueblo Revival duplexes priced $129,000 to $300,000 with quick access to Druid Hill Park, local dining, farmers markets and Mondawmin Mall.

name: Wilson Park
description: Founded in 1917, Baltimore’s Wilson Park in Baltimore is a historically African American community. It features Willow Avenue Park, Springfield Woods and dining spots like Cool Running Jamaican Cuisine and Chicken Run Carry-Out.

name: Parkside
description: Parkside in Baltimore borders Herring Run Park, a 375-acre green space. The area features classic row homes, close to bodegas and fast food options. Downtown attractions and the Inner Harbor are within about 4 miles.

name: Belair-Edison
description: Belair-Edison in Baltimore is surrounded by Herring Run Park and Clifton Park. In between are blocks of rowhouses, bungalows and Cape Cods. There are more than 50 local businesses in the neighborhood's commercial district.

name: Evergreen Lawn
description: Evergreen Lawn in Baltimore has row houses near parks like Helen Mackall and Gwynns Falls/Leakin. Shopping is convenient at Westside Shopping Center, and there is easy access to downtown via public transit or major routes.

name: Parklane
description: The community of Parklane in North Baltimore is a tiny neighborhood located just north of West Coldspring Lane. Featuring local park spaces and cozy homes, Parklane offers residents a quiet residential area with proximity to modern conveniences. name: Harlem Park
description: Harlem Park is a historic community in West Baltimore that's looking toward the future. Classic rowhomes fill the community, alongside several parks and small markets.

name: Towanda-Grantley
description: Towanda-Grantley blends city and suburban living with row houses from $145,000, detached homes from $23,000, Druid Hill Park, metro access and quick routes to BWI airport and Hampden.

name: Parkview-Woodbrook
description: Parkview-Woodbrook features 1920s rowhouses, ongoing restorations, access to Druid Hill Park and metro, plus shopping and dining at Mondawmin Mall, just 3 miles from downtown attractions.

name: Richnor Springs
description: Baltimore’s Richnor Springs offers traditional rowhomes and easy access to York Road amenities. This small, dense neighborhood is centrally located, offering convenience to downtown and uptown Baltimore.

name: Baltimore-Linwood
description: Baltimore-Linwood, 3 miles east of downtown Baltimore, features early 1900s rowhouses. Patterson Park offers outdoor recreation. Local amenities include corner markets and Echo Bar & Grill. The area has convenient access to public transportation and I-895.

name: Allendale
description: Allendale has a history dating back to the 1920s and features traditional two-story row homes with brick facades. Amenities are nearby, including shopping at Edmonson Village Shopping Center. Downtown Baltimore is also nearby.

name: McElderry Park
description: McElderry Park in Baltimore is a thriving community with lots of renovated row houses. The neighborhood is near Patterson Park and offers easy access to Northeast Market, Johns Hopkins Hospital, and downtown attractions.

name: Lakeland
description: Lakeland is a South Baltimore neighborhood, with brick rowhouses and colorful single-family homes. Residents can visit Lakeland Park or nearby Middle Branch Park, and access nearby Light Rail stations and BWI Airport in minutes.

name: Lucille Park
description: Lucille Park park in Baltimore has brick row houses that vary in condition. The area includes Jack Paulsen Park and Langston Hughes Community Center. Public transit options include Metro and bus routes along Reisterstown Road.

name: Saint Joseph's
description: Saint Joseph's in Baltimore is rooted in history and anchored by the Saint Joseph’s Monastery Parish. It hosts the highly rated Mount Saint Joseph High School, and historic brick row houses and duplexes.

name: Coldstream Homestead Montebello
description: Coldstream Homestead Montebello in East Baltimore is an active neighborhood, where residents meet for clean-ups and community walks among historic rowhouses. There are many nearby parks, and shops and restaurants line Harford Road and Greenmount Avenue.

name: Morrell Park
description: Morrell Park features traditional row houses and city skyline views. It’s close to downtown Baltimore, shopping, the Gwynns Falls Trail and Carroll Park Golf Course. Children attend Baltimore City Public Schools.

name: Bridgeview-Greenlawn
description: Bridgeview-Greenlawn in Baltimore is a transitional area featuring 1920s Federal-style row houses. The neighborhood is 3 miles from the downtown area and is situated between Gwynns Falls/Leakin Park and Druid Hill Park, close to the city and extensive recreation.

name: Carroll-South Hilton
description: Carroll-South Hilton in Baltimore features 1940s brick row homes. It’s close to Mount Olivet and Phelps Lane Park, Gwynns Falls/Leakin Park and Westside Shopping Center. Kids attend Baltimore City Public Schools.

name: Berea
description: Berea, an East Baltimore neighborhood, is known for its historic rowhouses and quiet streets. It offers convenient access to downtown, nearby shopping centers and outdoor spaces like Clifton Park and Baltimore Cemetery.

name: Curtis Bay
description: Curtis Bay in Baltimore blends industrial and residential areas with community gardens, recreation centers, and bay views. Locally owned eateries are within a short distance and commuters have easy access to downtown Baltimore.

name: Central Park Heights
description: Central Park Heights offers new development, Federal and Greek Revival row houses, red brick duplexes, a Main Street district, local parks, dining and metro connectivity in Northwest Baltimore.

name: Ellwood Park
description: Ellwood Park in Baltimore has traditional red-brick row houses. The namesake Ellwood Park and nearby Patterson Park offer green spaces and recreational facilities. Route 40 and public transit provide access to downtown, which is just 3 miles away.

name: East Baltimore Midway
description: East Baltimore Midway offers urban living with historic rowhouses and community gardens. Neighborhood highlights include Clifton Park and the National Great Blacks in Wax Museum.

name: Langston Hughes
description: Langston Hughes in Baltimore features brick row houses for lower prices near the Rogers Ave Metro Station. The C.C. Jackson Recreation Center and Pimlico Race Course are nearby. Shops and restaurants are on Reisterstown Road.

name: Madison-Eastend
description: Madison-Eastend in Baltimore features early 20th-century brick row homes near sports fields at Frank C. Bocek Park. The area is walkable with several public transit options and easy access to Patterson Park and the Johns Hopkins Medical campus.

name: Mondawmin
description: Mondawmin in Baltimore features classic row homes near Mondawmin Mall and Druid Hill Park. Coppin State University is a local landmark. Public transportation options connect residents to downtown Baltimore and beyond.

name: Four By Four
description: Four By Four is a small neighborhood in northeast Baltimore featuring traditional rowhouses near Clifton Park and Herring Run Park. Shopping complexes, bus stops and a public library are available in and around the neighborhood.

name: Biddle Street
description: Biddle Street in Baltimore features historic row homes near Johns Hopkins Hospital. This compact neighborhood is home to Eager Park, which has a community garden and a playground. There are a few local shops, and residents have access to transit.
